skills.name: Use direct proportion to solve non-unitary missing amounts in problems (e.g. recipes)
Write a given ratio in the form 1:n
Given information about one part, work out other parts
Find missing values when given equivalent ratios

explanations.A: I think you have divided the 1 litre in the ratio 4:1. Remember the 1 litre is all water. What part of the ratio is this?
explanations.B: Almost, this is how much orange juice will be needed in total. How much does she have already?
explanations.C: First, change all measurements to the same units: 1000 ml water and 100 ml juice. The ratio tells us that water makes up 4 parts, and we will focus on this because all of this is used up. We can write 4 parts = 1000 ml, so 1 part = 1000 ÷ 4 = 250 ml. This 250 ml is the amount of juice needed, being the appropriate 1 part. However, Lucy already has 100 ml, and so only an additional 150 ml is required.
explanations.D: I think you shared 1 litre in the ratio 4 : 1 and then subtracted the 100ml of juice that Lucy has. The 1 litre is just water, what part of the ratio represents water?

explanations.A: First, change all measurements to the same units: 2000 ml sparkling water and 200 ml juice. The ratio tells us that sparkling water makes up 5 parts, and we will focus on this because all of this is used up. We can write 5 parts = 2000 ml, so 1 part = 2000 ÷ 5 = 400 ml. The mixture, however, requires 2 parts of juice, so 800 ml is the amount required. Remember, Olive already has 200 ml, and this means only an additional 600 ml is needed.

explanations.A: I think you thought the second number stayed the same. Whatever we divide the first number by, we divide the second number by too
